74240407200D49EF8BA7D3CA05727805.description: Develop and/or revise personal and career goals based on the work placement experience.

10761591F20B41DF9F49D6B73287F85E.description: Prepare a letter, note, card or other communication for the work placement employer, expressing appreciation.

A976C5F4DFFF49E78AA0DCD22F5F7D21.description: Update personal career documentation (e.g., resume, portfolio) following the work placement.

9F52F1C7F39645688F449EACC5817BF5.description: Reflect on the attainment of personal and learning goals.

4F5B681949CC4AF3A3933BBBC302AD5A.description: Showcase one’s skills and abilities demonstrated during the work placement using artifacts, evidence of skill development and personal reflections on aspects of the work experience such as: hours worked; responsibilities and tasks performed; the importance of attitude towards work and taking responsibility for what needs to be done; details about the entry level wage, salary scales and earning potential; worker rights and responsibilities and the role of the union, if applicable; ownership structure (e.g., corporation, franchise, sole proprietorship, partnership); and, opportunities for advancement at the workplace and elsewhere in the industry.

2C91A297E2A14403A6BD19E6A749883C.description: Relate one’s work placement experience to personal and career goals

143DB7A5402246C09967758C36A97DA3.description: Document knowledge and awareness of employment standards, safety, workplace ethics, rights and responsibilities, occupational health and safety, and networking observed during the work placement.

C48C2C16F1B94E509C2E711A84DB0CA0.description: Document one’s experience using electronic and other tools (e.g., vlogs, blogs, log sheets, reflective journals) to summarize and reflect upon items such as: hours of work including breaks; • responsibilities and tasks performed; interactions with the employer, staff, customers and others; company or organization’s ‘raison d’être;’ and, skills developed and demonstrated during the work placement that enhance one’s employability.

604365780D8E4737BA9A92C101A1CB58.description: Apply relevant skills and abilities during the work placement experience.

77474FE65BF048B1BDBD9968ABB89D4B.description: Participate in a work placement experience.

B374F2A8B7124C0FBC9EF92BA784914C.description: Reflect upon one’s performance during the interview

6520F6918AB74B4EA8F7E2178A728F71.description: Participate in an interview with the employer prior to beginning the work placement.

D1DA9260D013471690A8CADDCCC0CDEF.description: Develop a list of questions that could potentially be asked by the employer/work placement in an interview situation as well as answers to the questions

8772F432D8B6446A815F610757E37DF3.description: Brainstorm a list of questions to ask the employer before beginning the work placement; these may include: What is my schedule of work hours? Who is my supervisor? What should I wear? When will I be provided with safety training? What potential hazards might I encounter in the work placement? Where do I find fire extinguishers, first aid kits and emergency assistance? What type of safety gear am I expected to wear? Is it provided? What should I do if I get injured or have an accident in the workplace? How can I contact my health and safety committee or representative? Are there any health and safety procedures I should follow? Who is the first aid person? Where are safety notices posted? What should I do in case of a fire or emergency?

7C22C2FE6CF9454CAFD0340E67C1FF48.description: Compile an employer information package that includes documents needed for the work placement (e.g., personal career documentation such as a resume or portfolio, permission forms, logs, self- and employer evaluation forms).

845F25B48BF143ABBB36CB39DBC5C5CC.description: Develop a procedural guide for the work placement that includes items such as: transportation to and from the work placement; hours of work; guidelines for absence and tardiness; dress code; job description; and, conflict resolution

47EC9641DF8F41FE84A3B93DBEC676AD.description: In collaboration with all partners, develop personal and learning goals for the work placement

95AC4EDB50C049288821C3AE237BC39F.description: Research the business/organization to become familiar with its operations

16AAB8D670894ED49D73FFFD5AA5DF92.description: Explain the roles and responsibilities of each partner (e.g., student, parent, teacher or other school staff, employer) involved in the work placement.

B32AC73A84854D118B949454A8511029.description: Describe and reflect on the three basic rights that all workers have under Part III – Occupational Health and Safety in The Saskatchewan Employment Act, 2019: the right to know – the hazards at work and how to control them; the right to participate – in finding and controlling workplace hazards; and, the right to refuse – work that you believe is unusually dangerous.

B2BAA89820584B24B98D8CE2A57434D8.description: Investigate the process for becoming a volunteer searcher in Saskatchewan.

CCE880C065054FDC8136C40CF1872177.description: Assess hazards (e.g., environmental, animals, insects) associated with SAR.

DA92BDBD6DDA451EA4D10F154F17B8BC.description: Discuss the physical and psychological demands associated with being a basic level searcher

85174126992346D29BEDECD034FA8766.description: Investigate the skills and abilities (e.g., team player, communication skills, professionalism, responsibility) required of a basic level search and rescue volunteer.

E95DEF7FDBC34161AEDF6088906AE250.description: Explain the general responsibilities associated with the three levels of searchers (i.e., searcher, team leader, manager) involved in a search and rescue (SAR) mission.

F82373C3A126410AB5B70F6F52B8923B.description: Describe the support that the Canadian Rangers provide to SAR in Northern and other areas of Saskatchewan.

3C4D09E497CF439FAD48709445C8C146.description: Identify SAR chapters in Saskatchewan and the communities they serve, including those that serve First Nations communities (e.g., Prince Albert Grand Council Search, Rescue and Recovery; Southern Saskatchewan First Nations SAR; La Loche Dene Trackers)

840AA76DB5784F00A89150850EE2EAC4.description: Investigate the origins of SARSAV and SARVAC.

60816F2512594E5EB74A584ECAEA54DC.description: Examine the organization and implementation of SAR services in Saskatchewan and in Canada, including the roles of the Search and Rescue Saskatchewan Association of Volunteers (SARSAV) and the Search and Rescue Volunteer Association of Canada (SARVAC).

F1ED1547A1C642119EB6E97AA4A00DDC.description: Discuss the purpose of search and rescue (SAR) services.

E5BE142C9BCE4617AB436F08C1D5418C.description: Examine the purpose and provision of search and rescue services in Saskatchewan and Canada.

EE45F5E61BA54E0294EF4CFC99894766.description: An Introduction to Search and Rescue

2E0784B144D14EC7B0D496876B00EC4A.description: Research the application process to become a police officer (e.g., city, RCMP, First Nation authority) in Saskatchewan.

14F47350C9854B369ADCF9167FDF7EFB.description: Investigate training options (e.g., city police, RCMP Depot, justice studies) to become a Police officer in Saskatchewan

C7BDE21DF942462587B013EE38A6979B.description: Identify policing services available locally and in other areas of Saskatchewan.

6299E9828FED44ABBAA54477125D421E.description: Research responsibilities associated with each level of policing in Canada.

3504E698DE254705A9C28FD0A67F4EB4.description: List the three levels (i.e., federal, provincial, municipal) of policing available in Canada

B0379FB3AE644E69A6B260DE04D7C542.description: Differentiate between the duties of police and security officers

477D5EFD96954F168C280559B0FBAF5A.description: Investigate police and security services in Saskatchewan.

C0FBEA89478B4BF192DFEF843575FB8C.description: Investigate the role that EMS plays in organ donation.

7388A7207A064AD1BD52838B6289D434.description: Research essential and basic skills used by EMS providers, including the provision of care for: airway emergencies; breathing and circulation emergencies; respiratory and cardiac arrest; wounds; head and spine injuries; bone, muscle and joint injuries; and, sudden medical emergencies such as seizures, environmental emergencies and poisons.

47E09A7B679C4A44B6B2FCD192FCABC0.description: Examine the roles and responsibilities of various levels of EMS including: emergency medical responder; primary care paramedic; advanced care paramedic; critical care paramedic; and, community paramedic

18F272415A3E4755A3660DACD5A9CB06.description: Investigate additional locations (e.g., industrial, mines, mental health and addictions organizations, health care facilities) in which paramedics are utilized.

60444146F0F5427491CB173A978EE8EC.description: Discuss additional services (e.g., regular visits/health checks to underserviced populations such as the homeless) provided by paramedics in Saskatchewan

C46B2D755CB343E298083007C7E5DCA0.description: Identify different environments (e.g., industrial, urban, rural, facilities such as police stations and hospitals) in which EMS personnel provide care.

4975C9BDCD484199B0A48F05596B9A8A.description: Research the process, qualifications and training required for becoming a member of a medical first responder team in Saskatchewan.

E67B2AEBB8B34778A5012215C4AE6BF0.description: Examine the role of medical first responder teams in the local region.

7FFEC67983BA45679719E0C6CD56594D.description: Identify the services provided locally by EMS.

81DEC4083F704E68B972B5FDBC46B551.description: Describe the purpose of Emergency Medical Services (EMS)

83A3E98699FC40B88AD02B4004928BF2.description: Analyze the role of emergency medical services in Saskatchewan

163D3DA676D449BDAD69B3BBBDCF9E68.description: Justify the selection of PPE appropriate for a variety of firefighting scenarios.

3A9DE84B6E5149FE97EA02A30032F089.description: Practise donning and doffing PPE in a variety of circumstances including darkness.

F2C9C8A21B0E44B5B0B32D0C59E4801B.description: Assess problems (e.g., restricted visibility, weight, heat tolerance) associated with a variety of firefighting PPE and clothing.

2FF262BEEFF04831BCCECA47823BD965.description: Examine characteristics and features of firefighting PPE and clothing that make them effective.

55ABBC46142643EF96E6F421C2491E59.description: Describe when, where and how specific pieces of firefighting PPE and clothing could be used.

47C7A11614C94EBABF42496C36651397.description: Investigate the types of firefighting PPE and clothing (e.g., gloves, boots, undergarments, helmets, face shields, goggles, respirators, gas masks).

BCDF7C40659F4E53913D4B9982F8231D.description: Identify hazards (e.g., excessive heat, smoke, dust, fumes) commonly faced by firefighters

474D98E4D91E4DBABE8787A9F10491CD.description: Assess the use of personal protective equipment and clothing in firefighting.

B3F54F96935B483186A21C497A465FF2.description: Personal Protective Equipment and Clothing for Firefighting (Optional)

D5DA3BA89EA04E42A21E48527DC00445.description: Recommend extinguishing agent(s) for a variety of fire-burning scenarios.

C28855BBEA6646A296260E3C42F76921.description: Demonstrate effective methods (e.g., lobbing, direct application, bouncing it off the ground) for applying various extinguishing agents.

18E5626E9ECA4832B1C09DA041A27763.description: Assess the effectiveness and limitations of each agent in extinguishing all classes of fire

111C7612C41B4BFF894B9DB605CB5E1A.description: Investigate other ways to extinguish a fire using common objects or materials such as dirt or sand, a blanket or baking soda.

E66CD0738826439387D7F7A08371AC9B.description: Examine types of fire extinguishing agents (i.e., water, foam, dry powder, carbon dioxide, wet chemical).

412D4AD1E32040AB9A46474D655389FF.description: Describe the principle of fire extinguishment through cooling, smothering or starvation.

3D45FB4A0FCF4D0CBBBF8C56CF507694.description: Explain the classes of fire, including: A - combustible materials such as paper and wood; B - flammable liquids such as paint and petrol; C - flammable gasses such as butane and methane; D - flammable metals such as lithium and potassium; K - kitchen fire fueled by flammable cooking liquids such as vegetable oils or cooking grease.

AED0C6B983394696A374489FFE361EBC.description: Identify the three basic elements of fire (i.e., oxygen, heat, fuel) known as the fire tetrahedron.

05424416A5AA403D9B3F5924DBF6F929.description: Demonstrate the Pull, Aim, Squeeze, Sweep (PASS) method for safely operating a fire extinguisher to put out fires contained within a fire pan, with the support of the local fire department.

62A193D0D4824F15ABF0E5108DF77E7D.description: Examine the process for safely disposing of a fire extinguisher.

2B6174761AA8478FBFFA07CC19DCEEF2.description: Assess the service life of a traditional and disposable fire extinguisher and the factors that might put them out of service.

2B910FEFD0784C87887C905852B09E89.description: Describe the importance of, and steps for, safely storing, inspecting (e.g., monthly, yearly), testing and maintaining a portable fire extinguisher.

9529FE6CC6014BA8BC6E40EBEF1A4C02.description: Examine the relationship among the various parts of a fire extinguisher

282A6DD669414ADFAEABDE46380E5048.description: Identify the parts of a fire extinguisher, including: cylinder containing the extinguishing agent and a propellant; release system comprised of a squeeze handle, a valve assembly and a release lever; gauge with over/under pressure indicator; safety mechanism comprised of a tamper seal and a pull pin; and, hose for directing the extinguishing agent.

4BA15C9AFD714B719320817187EC8883.description: Research the cost and availability of fire extinguishers for various locations (e.g., home, school, work).

214A0B92752C472983149B4B9C0692F4.description: Describe the characteristics, capabilities and limitations of three main types of portable fire extinguishers (i.e., water, CO2, dry chemical).

CAA9E0E409D44C0798E32C93BE875DA0.description: Examine the storage, maintenance and use of portable fire extinguishers.

89F92C093F9F4EA6BA06137E29E53769.description: Examine circumstances when ICS would not be initiated in Saskatchewan and Canada.

DD9188C4921549D7B2A6D25DACD1C599.description: Identify instances (e.g., fire; traffic accident; natural disasters such as tornadoes, floods and blizzards; human and animal disease outbreaks; search and rescue missions; planned events such as parades, demonstrations and concerts) when ICS might be initiated in Saskatchewan and Canada

9947A39FCA1D4FA4AEDE695D9472687B.description: Discuss the three primary purposes of ICS, including providing for the: safety of responders and others; achievement of measurable objectives; and, efficient use of resources.

92FDF3ABB75240599F3D3796327D298F.description: Research the origin of the ICS including its introduction into Canada and Saskatchewan

EEF33F1BE8474375B4560BEEB2B714FE.description: Explain the benefits of ICS and the cooperation among many local, provincial and federal agencies that support it.

AC2A3F2A0FBE431DB877751A28A84C77.description: Analyze the role of the Incident Command System in managing an emergency incident or planned event.

D60638156A614AE89353BC44887FD43A.description: Create a list of guidelines (e.g., drive with due care; turn on emergency warning lights when parked on a road; park safely and away from hazardous areas such as downed electrical lines, falling debris and smoke) for the safe operation of an emergency vehicle.

8FE4A87CF7AC400E84AF0D900EDFA839.description: Research driver qualifications, training requirements and licensing requirements for operating a variety of emergency vehicles including ambulance, fire truck and car in Saskatchewan

49478457535D46A1ACFD0D8356D870BE.description: Examine conditions that might lead to wake-effect collisions related to emergency vehicles.

EE43B8E84AE04756A8211D7442F9DED6.description: Identify usage and meaning of various colours for emergency vehicle lights.

0B6020DA00B24BB5A5209271CFA6B36E.description: Describe a driver’s legal responsibility and response to an emergency vehicle sounding a siren, displaying flashing lights and approaching or stopped on the road in Saskatchewan.

F2DC24FE856A419A9FEAC3F33E75B6E2.description: Examine provincial laws (e.g., Saskatchewan Traffic Safety Act) and local bylaws that protect all drivers on Saskatchewan and community roads

43B47206E2CF4CDDB3426A4DE2EE5D72.description: Research Saskatchewan and Canadian statistics related to incidents, injuries and fatalities resulting from vehicle collisions/mishaps associated with emergency vehicles (e.g., emergency services personnel responding to, returning from, or working at an emergency).

9F427E130FDC4FD6B49EFD4BC3EE21E8.description: Examine features and criteria of emergency vehicles in Saskatchewan.

2EA090DB53F54B419C6A5F6468511F9C.description: Analyze the safe operation of emergency vehicles in Saskatchewan.

15497DB6112745B49E7A8CB2D66D9942.description: Differentiate among the hot, warm and cold zones within an emergency scene.

14A7C7BF715A43EB9BA4A4A05E52F104.description: Identify ways to have bystanders assist (e.g., calling 911, assist in administering first aid).

74CB0EB121A54E74ADBA7B78073F7898.description: Examine ways in which bystanders can help or hinder at an emergency scene

CEE969A1F0FC41D0A2ABA69356876E87.description: Describe the four steps of emergency scene management, including: surveying the scene – identifying hazards for self and others, including the casualty; primary survey - assessing for life-threatening conditions and for giving life-saving first aid; secondary survey – assessing for head-to-toe bleeding, lumps, hardness, bruising and softness; and, ongoing casualty care – continuing care until professional help arrives.

07354B6965484A42B25DFDC46C074ACD.description: Identify scene safety considerations according to the POPP (i.e., People, Odours, Pets, Pathways) strategy.

46274599B7614059930A604A9E5F50D7.description: Explain the importance of ‘safety first’ when it comes to responding to an emergency scene and the importance of early access to medical services when required by an injured person.

9C96766D305A41419CF5D11482AB16EA.description: Differentiate between the typical reaction (e.g., panic, fear) and the helpful reaction (e.g., calmness, taking charge) that is required when encountering an emergency scene.

36522275D7E741BFB4FE307F6D2FF621.description: Research the legal protection (e.g., The Good Samaritan Act) for Saskatchewan citizens who provide emergency medical services or first aid assistance as first on scene.

A2B41C31689D4478BA0CC9AB10FE4823.description: Assess steps for managing an emergency scene.

39BB84F14C93411E95A3F2B1A8503ADB.description: Examine elements of the LOCPRESS acronym for monitoring vital signs, including LOC – level of consciousness, P – pulse, R – respiration; E – eyes; S – skin colour; and, S – skin temperature.

5CF6950E5C3D4DB780CE60B5B3B15EE2.description: Assess the vital signs (i.e., consciousness, breathing, pulse, skin temperature, pupils) to be monitored while treating an injured person, and the frequency (e.g., every 5 to 10 minutes) for doing so.

91BC3094B2C741C781B1C86152302CB8.description: Propose questions to be asked when following the SAMPLE history mnemonic for an individual’s medical assessment, including: What seems to be bothering you? (Signs and symptoms), Do you have any allergies I should know about? (Allergies), Are you on any medication? (Medications), Has this happened to you before? (Past medical history), When was your last meal? Did you have breakfast/lunch/dinner? (Last oral intake), What were you doing when this happened? (Event)

68E9D208933F46C79738D1D9C35FEE4A.description: Examine the APVU (i.e., Alert, Verbal, Pain, Unresponsive) scale that helps determine a patient’s level of consciousness.

BE6F564BF2264E1B92E22D2B87CC950D.description: Research ways to assess the following in an injured person: airway patency; effective breathing; pulse; and, different types of bleeding (i.e., capillary, venous and arterial).

AA43849CB8E74520AAD19DC7F7E665D1.description: Describe elements (e.g., posture, facial expression, sitting position, breathing that interferes with the ability to speak) of an initial general assessment that might provide diagnostic clues to the patient condition or illness

56270982C9024F6197ED4B73BA17F7A7.description: Assess the importance of searching a patient’s wrist and neck for medical identification jewellery

E93A6026C3CF4025932378A6B68FFEAD.description: Identify the purpose of medical identification jewellery (e.g., bracelet, neckpiece).

A5C340D575EA4C75B56F8515CE3203D5.description: Investigate strategies for assessing a patient during an emergency.

BFDE895F63EB474D80C373677AFB41CD.description: Explore the additional actions that may be required when administering first aid in rural and remote areas.

0BC7EBFC05B04D0DB011916C0ADF9459.description: Propose appropriate initial responses to a variety of given scenarios where first aid is required.

4FF20D20C5174DB2BA25C4431C8C311F.description: Differentiate between time-critical (e.g., heart attack, cardiac arrest, stroke, severe allergic reactions, severe trauma, breathing [e.g., asthma and/or anaphylaxis, apnea]) and non-time-critical (e.g., minor cuts or bruises, rash, sprain) medical emergencies.

28DA7B45205F4B4FA7BD16C1136EF5DE.description: Identify potential actions (e.g., calling 911) and equipment used to assist in providing the ABCD basics of basic first aid.

D5D6F030B78A406DA1FFBA0F2982DEB4.description: Examine the ABCD basics of basic first aid including: Airway – Does the patient have an open airway? Breathing – Is the patient breathing? Is it effective breathing? Circulation – Does the patient have a pulse? Deadly Bleeding – Is the patient bleeding, and if so, how badly?

5A5E7FC31B504816AFE503990BA7A688.description: Discuss the three P’s or aims of first aid to: preserve life; prevent the injury or illness from getting worse; and, promote recovery

3D74FBC46E9B4943A78CD374A3864515.description: Define the terms, first aid and first aider and Good Samaritan Act.

87869195122C4CD48218742B50F5BE26.description: Examine basic first aid used by all emergency services personnel.

6E7CCF41C19F495DA12A562EB269814F.description: Research ways that social media could be used effectively to manage communications during an emergency.

55C49DB2334C4324A9EFE56C6938B90D.description: Investigate the consequences (e.g., to self, others and community) of misuse of social media by bystanders to an emergency situation.

960BEA45BDCA4D3B9D857FE430538F9D.description: Discuss the advantages (e.g., instantaneous messaging; supporting various media such as text, video and audio; audience reach) and disadvantages (e.g., short, concise messages may be misunderstood; loss of control of a message after it is sent; limited audience reach) associated with using social media to communicate with the public during an emergency

DCC8D403E17F4586B1B841AFC4DB1C62.description: Identify examples of emergency communications using common social media platforms.

624DDA6FF5D94569B07A9CE5FDF71219.description: Analyze the use of social media as a communication tool during an emergency.

0E2C926D8F0D497797AF8D3530683280.description: Identify basic communications equipment used in telecommunications centres as well as public alerting systems.

953258947B6F4BEFA27008275FDA7978.description: Investigate the purpose and use of alert systems (e.g., SaskAlert, Amber Alert, Silver Alert) in Saskatchewan and Canada.

1E7F3A464B5A409E99F580AD0C13C31E.description: Examine the adaptation of 10 codes for law enforcement at the local level.

FC995D2EB4F44A359C96C9319C949030.description: Research the origin, purpose and current use of 10 codes.

A0600CC477AF4211A2A6FCB18EF44807.description: Describe the purpose and components of a Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) in an emergency situation

B29D927D7C63467382C689421CDCC9A4.description: Transmit and receive radio, interpersonal and written messages in a mock emergency.

63109E994E5F4D0383F90E1DD876FC17.description: Examine proper procedures for sending and receiving radio messages while using the Provincial Public Safety Telecommunications Network (PPSTN).

82DC0F0F2C314026933D5864E27BE451.description: Gather information and compose messages as part of a mock emergency

4B25553A9860439E90E33DDE9FA9F99A.description: Describe instances when an LCAN report could be used in emergency communications.

91DFA4D2DC0745D19E92C494FD051B3A.description: Describe the purpose and components of a Location, Conditions, Actions, Needs (LCAN) report

A7A00924780749D1A5812535AD10E946.description: Explore tips for basic etiquette (e.g., introduce oneself immediately, speak clearly, listen intently) that contribute to effective communication via telephone

49A638A5174D4A5FAD4A550C616251BA.description: Converse with others using the phonetic alphabet.

B69509850953471CB18CDAD07B3F60A1.description: Research the purpose, composition and current usage of the phonetic alphabet in emergency communications.

CCC1AB155077466ABF2B0845A94081B0.description: Justify the most appropriate communication method for a variety of given emergency situations.

43664EDA31E34D7B8D83BF60DAFC25F5.description: Identify the methods (i.e., radio/telecommunications, interpersonal, written/data) of emergency communications.

29ADD4F7D46C4D2E9CE5F8359C605190.description: Describe the interpersonal skills required of those working or assisting at an emergency.

AA810C13F79043C3AE61D8C097CBE851.description: Examine strategies for communicating effectively during an emergency.

65A470E8D0374CB3BD040D914979F455.description: Discuss the importance of effective communication during an emergency.

0619155D9D5449E3BD8A21B27C9EDD00.description: Investigate the importance and application of effective communications during an emergency.

015D763D45C24030900A1D32855E7588.description: Reflect on personal beliefs and unconscious bias, and their potential impact on the ability to work or volunteer in emergency services.

B65E5AC282834878A478EFF871444DC4.description: Explore strategies (e.g., using iSpeak cards or pictures to communicate, subscribing to interpretation and translation services) used by emergency services personnel to effectively assist and communicate with individuals from diverse backgrounds and with diverse needs.

F734CB3CF3664F52A2C6E4909D7CE4B1.description: Research the potential impact of discrimination based on factors such as ancestry, nationality, creed, gender, sexual orientation and age on the provision of emergency services.

763FEB271F9D4D0F9930F3FCE2AEC724.description: Discuss the importance of cultural and linguistic literacy and competency for emergency services personnel.

8B2BF555C32E4F70900D842D39659AD3.description: Analyze the diversity (e.g., cultural, linguistic, demographic) in the local community, Saskatchewan and Canada.

B5A413A733E14B56814B85F82DEE2FF8.description: Assess approaches used by emergency services personnel in supporting diverse populations in the community.

337D300DA5664A8CB16CED8B232D128D.description: Identify credible Saskatchewan and Canadian sources that offer supports for emergency services personnel experiencing psychological health challenges and for their family members.

879F875BF80F443AB5E9609BF1938AD4.description: Discuss characteristics (e.g., registered, licensed, evidence-based) of a credible source for psychological support.

E638AE85463D459CAD914D050DB1D1AE.description: Research ways in which others (e.g., family, co-workers, friends) can support emergency services personnel facing psychological health challenges.

E0B583AB74F7466C97991B89E9989205.description: Investigate self-care strategies (e.g., writing in a journal, talking to others such as family and co-workers about feelings and experiences, practising breathing and relaxation techniques, maintaining a healthy diet, getting adequate sleep and exercise) that support mental health and well-being of emergency services personnel.

4229422940B64153BA8297F1D6E48DAA.description: Assess the purpose of, and steps associated with, the Critical Incident Stress Debriefing process as a traumatic intervention tool commonly used among emergency services workers.

CD7E66012454470E9C36D8001103BFFB.description: Discuss the impact of psychological health challenges faced by emergency services personnel on self and others (e.g., family, co-workers, friends).

2AEA6208D95D46929106CCF3E1358E40.description: Research statistics related to suicidal ideation, plans and attempts among emergency services personnel in Canada.

7B3893EA8DAD4D3E81723E8CCD2B5E88.description: Describe the personal feelings, symptoms and behaviours commonly associated with various psychological health challenges.

C91156B2F6464935AFF13D1411F1D994.description: Examine statistics related to the prevalence of psychological health challenges among emergency services personnel in Canada.

BF2BAF1DC9BC4C9FA3F522D299E6F671.description: Identify mental health challenges such as Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD), major depressive disorder, general anxiety disorder, social anxiety disorder, panic disorder and alcohol use disorder commonly experienced by emergency services personnel.

D9798F42D5C949FA8370176B5792C7D9.description: Research sources of stress (e.g., traumatic events, shift work, separation from family, public disrespect) commonly experienced by emergency services personnel.

59345E868C264D1EBB1D20897E9B3ABB.description: Discuss the correlation between personal psychological preparedness and the ability to respond effectively in an emergency.

8D45C1883BB74F08A600F83A340A2011.description: Examine the state of psychological health and well-being among emergency services personnel in Canada.

8AD172E91AC444AEB24BF31AC9847AEF.description: Research employer responsibilities pertaining to PPE (e.g., training employees on the usage, limitations, care, maintenance, proper disposal) in Saskatchewan.

0E7B54A898C6479690700F8DA2D4D89C.description: Identify types of PPE worn by various emergency services personnel.

CA80076E8E2F460B945BCA25273DF598.description: Discuss the need for, and importance of, proper-fitting PPE and clothing

F76664C658BD41DC9A8C91DAE64DCE19.description: Describe the purpose of Personal Protective Equipment (PPE)

1E4CE2F9351C4747A4CEFE8C7B5A76BA.description: Assess statistics related to workplace injuries for emergency services personnel in Saskatchewan and Canada.

26C95E51985A40D0B6A1B3779022C084.description: Describe employers’ and employees’ rights and responsibilities pertaining to workplace hazards and how they can work together to prevent workplace hazards

DA28DF748859452F950961A1C2FD1F3E.description: Categorize examples of potential hazards that emergency services personnel may encounter.

60973986ACFB42DFA1E01FC1FEBCF056.description: Differentiate among the four Occupational Health and Safety hazard categories physical (e.g., heavy lifting, repetitive motion, slipping/tripping, working at heights, working alone, cuts, burns); chemical (e.g., chemicals, fumes, vapours, gases); biological (e.g., viruses, fungi, bacteria, mold; bodily fluids; sewage; animal/pet waste; influenza); and, psychological (e.g., harassment and bullying, stress, fatigue, shift work).

467F4DF8F6DA4D71806D36E8555F2E32.description: Assess workplace hazards and injury prevention related to emergency services.

A6F51E2175534FA69FF08CFE2F8601C1.description: Workplace Safety – Hazards and Injury Prevention (Core)

FD846596964B4EDFBC5783A3FD8BB08E.description: Develop a personal plan for pursuing a career or to volunteer in emergency services, considering criteria such as: initial and continuing educational and training requirements; duties and skills required for the occupation or volunteer position; work environment, including typical hours and shift work and typical locations; current wages received in Saskatchewan and how these compare to wages in other regions of Canada; physical, mental and emotional stresses related to the occupation; • workplace hazards and safety considerations; other occupations with which they interact; and, certification requirements in Saskatchewan and Canada.

D8663FA717374FF99B4F88744D277E89.description: Reflect on personal interests, skills, abilities and traits that could lead to a variety of career choices and volunteer opportunities in emergency services.

B0BC12C1E9E54C6FBAB7D9B3FBC67349.description: Explore opportunities for volunteering in emergency services within the local community.

90A1A975A04D4A62B780A3DB58DC9053.description: Identify current and forecasted career opportunities and employment trends, including labour surpluses or shortages, in emergency services in Saskatchewan and Canada.

EF05C545C96248D08348AFE171B26EB5.description: Interview an emergency services worker to gain an understanding of their role.

005079F4632844F7AEB26C4EF351E49B.description: Generate a list of questions to ask someone working in emergency services to learn about their work. Sample questions include: What do you do?, What knowledge and skills do you use every day?, What does a typical day look like?, What is the most challenging emergency you have faced in your career?, What motivates you to go to work every day?,  Why did you choose this career?.

393C8996C0C547EFACAAE66D3948EE0F.description: Research characteristics and skills common to those who work in emergency services.

9FFD8C1C3E574DAF8D8E85FD46B6E926.description: Investigate paid and volunteer career opportunities in emergency services.

B62EA86E3F9F45BCAD1630054B07EB43.description: Research the availability of services similar to Sask911 and associated telephone numbers in other parts of North America and the world.

DAA6EE82AD0F420CAB7FBFE050109F03.description: Determine actions to take if 911 is not available (e.g., no phone access, out of cell service, isolated area) during an emergency.

8FB40FE4AD55434A92A95C0BCE65FEBD.description: Examine the components of, and roles associated with, the Sask911 system including: public service answering points (i.e., located near Prince Albert, Saskatoon and Regina); dispatch life support; ambulance services; •medical first responder teams; and, emergency services.

A7F297B334014255A3DD4AC785ACEECF.description: Describe the response and support a caller to Sask911 should expect, including the sequence of events that typically unfold.

0D78BB5A3D8047FFBEF50A89B724991B.description: Create a list of tips (e.g., keep calm, know your location or surroundings, stay on the line) for being able to provide the information required by Sask911

B21B77314D0040A9B069D17FF9946E96.description: Discuss what to do if 911 is dialed accidentally.

A365154F7C5443B0B56CB739A3C73BE6.description: Investigate the consequences of placing a prank call to 911

E7AEC53B11C8434EBA2DFBB3A6532D40.description: Differentiate between responsible and irresponsible calls to the Sask911 system.

C6EEBBDF9D524951BBB9A7C825A78FBE.description: Investigate the availability and processes for qualifying for and accessing the text service for Sask911 as a Saskatchewan resident.

A729274BFFF147F59E2B0B86D8E12B96.description: Describe the purpose of, and services provided by, the Saskatchewan Public Safety Agency Sask911 system

7BE3D632ECEA429980B87BA3B7D82C53.description: Assess the role of the Sask911 system in supporting public safety in the province.

07264AF82C184E749D3ACB5D1DBFD361.description: Discuss factors (e.g., location, pay-per-user fees) that determine the availability of, and access to, emergency services.

6363BCB8027941A3B3AF89A5CC923D1C.description: Assess the availability of, and access to, emergency services locally and provincially.

AC1D8CDF37BB446BA07C06563867A380.description: Examine given scenarios to determine which level(s) (i.e., individuals, municipal responders, the provincial government, the federal government) of response may be required.

0973C44E1EF14D1DA4D00A07811B01F1.description: Describe the roles that individuals, municipal responders, provincial government and federal government play in emergency response in Saskatchewan and Canada

576203F9E1AF4A5AA97BBE2A9B25DEF7.description: Research activities that fall under each of the primary emergency services areas, such as: law enforcement, criminal investigation, maintenance of public order (police); fire suppression, technical rescue, hazardous materials mitigation (fire); ambulance, medical assessment and support of rescuers working in a hot zone (emergency medical services); and, search and rescue.

38BE450E57994C729451B1B77616AE9F.description: Identify the primary areas (e.g., police, fire, emergency medical services, search and rescue) that constitute emergency services in Saskatchewan and Canada.

0F6828A2701640E29B0057F07B8B9843.description: Differentiate between a first responder and an emergency responder.

185C21DC1A6748E3805EBE62EE4998D1.description: Discuss the role of emergency services in ensuring public safety and health.

9E160B1BC94A4D61BB3EA41B11A16595.description: Describe ways (e.g., reducing hazards in and around homes and workplaces, taking first aid training, learning how to use a fire extinguisher) to personally prepare for emergency situations.

F524372400544983A72F33CE0F9C7603.description: Reflect on personal responsibility for handling emergencies for self, family and others (e.g., friends, classmates, work colleagues).

83503CB5BE304CD5A00847E79553FBA1.description: Define the legal term, duty to act

633FCC29DCFF445ABEC708443F9C70E8.description: Analyze various components of local, provincial and national emergency services.
